author: mklement0
body:
<sup>Related: #4199</sup>

Currently, using `powershell -version <version>` may or may not be honored:

In PowerShell Core:
  * on _Unix_, _any_ version number is accepted, and _quietly falls back to the current version_.
  * on _Windows_,  the behavior is the same as in _Windows PowerShell_ v5.1 (see below).

In _Windows_ PowerShell:
 * Higher-than-the installed-version numbers are rejected (`Cannot start Windows PowerShell. No version of Windows PowerShell compatible to <version> is installed.`), 
  * Lower version numbers may or may not get honored (e.g., on a W10 system `powershell v2` actually starts v2, whereas `powershell v3`, `powershell v4`, and `powershell v5.0` quietly  fall back to v5.1) , and the only way to verify is to inspect `$PSVersionTable` inside the new session.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

On Unix:

```powershell
powershell -version 22.0
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

* With versions _higher_ than the highest available one: An error complaining that no such version is available, as currently on Windows.

* With version _lower_ than the highest available one, yet without the _specific_ requested one present, the expected behavior is debatable, but, if a new session is still started, at the very least there should be _some_ indication that the version being launched is not the one _specifically requested_.

Actual behavior
---------------

On Unix, _quietly_ starts the most recently installed version, no matter what version was requested.

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.0-beta.4 on macOS 10.12.5
PowerShell Core v6.0.0-beta.4 on Ubuntu 16.04.2 LTS
PowerShell Core v6.0.0-beta.4 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
Windows PowerShell v5.1.15063.413 on Microsoft Windows 10 Pro (64-bit; v10.0.15063)
```
title: CLI: powershell -version shouldn't quietly ignore the inability to start the explicitly requested version
